citeinfo.origin: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico
citeinfo.title: Continuous Water Quality MRG: I-25 2011

descript.abstract: Healthy aquatic ecosystems in arid land rivers have become increasingly important as climate change and swelling populations place greater strain upon already limited water resources. Little is known about the spatio-temporal patterns in the water quality of the Middle Rio Grande (MRG) which runs through major urban centers in arid New Mexico, and now provides drinking water for Albuquerque, NM. The rapidly urbanizing character of the MRG, such as urban storm drains and waste water treatment plants places numerous stressors linked to water quality on the biota of the river. The purpose of this monitoring and research program is to assess temporal and spatial trends for five water quality parameters (temperature, pH, conductivity, turbidity, and dissolved oxygen) and determine stream metabolism in the MRG using continuous, near real-time, data along the 60.3 river kilometers (37.5 miles) of the Albuquerque reach of the MRG. Monitoring was conducted at 4 research sites in the Greater Albuquerque area using multi-parameter water quality meters. Temperature trends displayed the expected yearly summer highs averaging 25 º - 30 º C and winter lows averaging ~0 º C. Conductivity measurements ranged widely and were responsive to local monsoon storms as well as fire debris-related discharge pulses originating in northern NM after the Las Conchas fire. Dissolved oxygen showed an inverse trend to temperature with summer lows and winter high and responded to 1) local storm pulses with frequently hypoxic DO sags and 2) fire-related discharge pulses with sustained hypoxia and anoxia. Turbidity data was highly variable and frequently above the range of the sensors. However, it was possible to determine that some turbidity spikes followed by gradual depletions were related to both local storm and upstream fire-related events. Data collected during this project demonstrate that WQ in the MRG is spatially and temporally variable and responsive to episodic occurrences such as monsoon storms and fire-related discharge events. These results indicate that multiple years of continued data collection are required to provide an accurate assessment of the response of MRG water quality to inter-annual climate variability, episodic events and resulting changes in river flow.
descript.purpose: The objectives of this study were to: 1) conduct a detailed assessment of the temporal and spatial trends in water quality and 2) determine stream metabolism of the Middle Rio Grande.
descript.supplinf: These data are made available through New Mexico's Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (NM EPSCoR) data portal. The portal provides access to data generated by and of use to the EPSCoR community including researchers, educators, and policy leaders, as well as the general public.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.4000

procstep.procdesc: YSI 6920 multi-parameter meters known as sondes were used to collect water quality data for the following five parameters: temperature, specific conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH and turbidity. Sondes were serviced, recalibrated and data downloaded approximately every two to four weeks following USGS Standard Operating Procedures (TM1-D3). A modified version of the USGS Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) was used before a calibration specific sonde (referred to as the lab sonde) was purchased with which to compare data readings from the field sondes. The modified version of the SOP was also used when a field sonde failed to work properly and the lab sonde was deployed in its place.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: All data files from each site were combined into a single yearly Excel file. Gaps in the data sets were filled with the characters -99999 to designate missing data.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: Columns designating the results of a preliminary QAQC procedure were created. These columns are designated as ‘Temp QA’, ‘Cond QA’, ‘DO QA’, ‘pH QA’ and ‘Turb QA’ and contain a ‘.’, ‘S’, or ‘X’ designating no QAQC flag, suspicious data, and missing, invalid, or unusual data, respectively.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: Data was compared to field notebook notes. Every possible or definite burial, out of water occurrence, battery drainage and equipment malfunction was noted.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: The combined datasets were imported into the Aquarius Time Series Software (ATSS) Data Correction Toolbox where corrections for probe fouling and drift were applied to the data and the preliminary QAQC designations were updated and added to when deemed necessary. Corrections were based on: a. Shifts resulting from recalibration b. Comparison of the target signal (signal being corrected) with reference signals from the same site (i.e. the dissolved oxygen signal which is subject to drift was compared to the more stable temperature signal (Fig. d.) from the same site as well as the conductivity signal (Fig. c.) that provides information about storm events). c. Comparison of the target signal with reference signals from upstream and downstream sites. d. Data were typically corrected using the one-point variable data correction method, as specified in ‘USGS Techniques and Methods 1-D3, Guidelines and Standard Procedures for Continuous Water-Quality Monitors: Station Operation, Record Computation, and Data Reporting’). e. The calibration procedure we used for our data collection differed in several respects from that of the USGS as specified in our Middle Rio Sonde Data Quality Assurance and Quality Control Plan. We used the total shifts measured between the last sample values recorded 1) prior to equipment removal and calibration, 2) prior to burials, 3) prior to equipment exposure to air due to drops in water depth, and in some case, 4) prior to battery depletion resulting in incorrect recordings; and the first stabilized values recorded post-calibration. When possible, the measurements of total shifts were used in conjunction with the measurements of shifts occurring during calibration to correct the data for both sensor fouling and calibration drift. Otherwise the total shifts measured were used to correct the data for the combined effects of sensor fouling and calibration drift Some uncertainty is associated with this method of data correction. A conservative interpretation of the corrected data would assign an uncertainty of ~ ±20% of the correction percent (i.e. data that received a 0-1% linear correction for drift over a calibration period would a have a correction range of 0.8 to 1.2 % at the end of the calibration period). f. When no data were available at the end of a data collection period (e.g. when the sonde had been buried or the batteries died part way through a deployment) no calibration could be performed. These data are flagged in the final dataset and should be viewed as suspect and used with caution.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: The raw combined dataset was scanned for outliers using the "Threshold" flagging option available in ATSS. Data were flagged when they fell outside the range specific to each parameter based upon both equipment and environmental limitations- temperature: -05.00 - 50.00 °C, conductivity: 0.100 - 100.000 mS cm-1, DO: 0.00 - 20.00 mg l-1, pH: 3.50 - 9.99 pH units, turbidity: 0.0 - 1000.0 NTU.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: The raw combined dataset was scanned for outliers using the ‘Rate of Change’ flagging option available in ATSS. Data were flagged when they exceeded a rate of change per hour specific to each parameter: temperature-0.5 °C, conductivity-10% mS cm-1, DO-0.5 mg l-1, pH-0.5 pH units, turbidity-10% NTU

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: Data were graded according to the percent correction made to the raw data using the USGS grading criteria as specified in USGS TM 1-D3. The grades are as follows: Excellent, Good, Fair, Poor.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: The corrected combined dataset was scanned for outliers using the "Threshold" flagging option available in ATSS. Data were flagged when they fell outside the range specific to each parameter based upon both equipment and environmental limitations- temperature: -05.00 - 30.00 °C, conductivity: 0.100 - 10.000 mS cm-1, DO: 0.00 - 20.00 mg l-1, pH: 3.50 - 9.99 pH units, turbidity: 0.0 - 1000.0 NTU.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: The individual datum in the corrected combined dataset was given a final quality assurance grade based upon the accumulation of all grades and scans.

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: Preliminary QAQC with Microsoft Excel software

cntorgp.cntorg: Department of Biology, University of New Mexico

procstep.procdesc: Final QAQC with Aquarius Time Series Software

attrdomv.udom: Comments from researcher can be in any format.

attr.attrdef: Date and time measurement was taken

Raw temperature data after all missing or significantly suspect data resulting from equipment removed from the river during calibration, high water flows, repairs, etc., missing data due to drained batteries or full memory, or the value, "-99999", which was put in place in order to represent the aforementioned data or lack thereof, have been removed from the data set.

Raw conductivity data after all missing or significantly suspect data resulting from equipment removed from the river during calibration, high water flows, repairs, etc., missing data due to drained batteries or full memory, or the value, "-99999", which was put in place in order to represent the aforementioned data or lack thereof, have been removed from the data set.

Raw dissolved oxygen ocncentration data after all missing or significantly suspect data resulting from equipment removed from the river during calibration, high water flows, repairs, etc., missing data due to drained batteries or full memory, or the value, "-99999", which was put in place in order to represent the aforementioned data or lack thereof, have been removed from the data set.

Raw pH data after all missing significantly suspect data resulting from equipment removed from the river during calibration, high water flows, repairs, etc., missing data due to drained batteries or full memory, or the value, "-99999", which was put in place in order to represent the aforementioned data or lack thereof, have been removed from the data set.

Raw turbidity data after all missing or significantly suspect data resulting from equipment removed from the river during calibration, high water flows, repairs, etc., missing data due to drained batteries or full memory, or the value, "-99999", which was put in place in order to represent the aforementioned data or lack thereof, have been removed from the data set.

This field is used to indicate whether the raw temperature data has passed the 2nd quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place.

edom.edomvd: data passed second quality assurance review

attr.attrdef: This field is used to indicate whether the raw temperature data has passed the 3rd quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings".

This field is used to indicate whether the raw conductivity data has passed the 2nd quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place.

attr.attrdef: This field is used to indicate whether the raw turbidity data has passed the 3rd quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings".

Corrected temperature data after 1) all significantly suspect data resulting from equipment malfunction, suspected-low/low/drained batteries, equipment burials and/or unsubmerged equipment has been removed from the data set, 2) initial data after calibration and deployment that reflect the equipment is still equilibration to the environment has been removed from data set, and 3) data exceeding the range of the equipment has been removed, 4) significant outliers, and 5) data has been corrected for calibration, fouling and/or overall drift.

Corrected conductivity data after 1) all significantly suspect data resulting from equipment malfunction, suspected-low/low/drained batteries, equipment burials and/or unsubmerged equipment has been removed from the data set, 2) initial data after calibration and deployment that reflect the equipment is still equilibration to the environment has been removed from data set, and 3) data exceeding the range of the equipment has been removed, 4) significant outliers, and 5) data has been corrected for calibration, fouling and/or overall drift.

Corrected dissolved oxygen concentration data after 1) all significantly suspect data resulting from equipment malfunction, suspected-low/low/drained batteries, equipment burials and/or unsubmerged equipment has been removed from the data set, 2) initial data after calibration and deployment that reflect the equipment is still equilibration to the environment has been removed from data set, and 3) data exceeding the range of the equipment has been removed, 4) significant outliers, and 5) data has been corrected for calibration, fouling and/or overall drift.

Corrected pH data after 1) all significantly suspect data resulting from equipment malfunction, suspected-low/low/drained batteries, equipment burials and/or unsubmerged equipment has been removed from the data set, 2) initial data after calibration and deployment that reflect the equipment is still equilibration to the environment has been removed from data set, and 3) data exceeding the range of the equipment has been removed, 4) significant outliers, and 5) data has been corrected for calibration, fouling and/or overall drift.

Corrected turbidity data after 1) all significantly suspect data resulting from equipment malfunction, suspected-low/low/drained batteries, equipment burials and/or unsubmerged equipment has been removed from the data set, 2) initial data after calibration and deployment that reflect the equipment is still equilibration to the environment has been removed from data set, and 3) data exceeding the range of the equipment has been removed, 4) significant outliers, and 5) data has been corrected for calibration, fouling and/or overall drift.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected temperature data has passed the 4th quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place. "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected temperature data has passed the 5th quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings". "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected conductivity data has passed the 4th quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place. "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

"Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected dissolved oxygen concentration data has passed the 4th quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place. "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected dissolved oxygen data has passed the 5th quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings". "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected pH data has passed the 4th quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place. "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected pH data has passed the 5th quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings". "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected turbidity data has passed the 4th quality assurance review by determining whether the data is 1) within the range of the recording instrument and 2) falls within the reasonable range of expected values given the environment in which the measurement took place. "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

This field is used to indicate whether the corrected turbidity data has passed the 5th quality assurance review by grading the rate of change between a given measurement and the previous measurement using the USGS TM 1-D3 Table 18: "Accuracy Ratings of Continuous Water-Quality Ratings". "Data_Missing" denotes data missing from the raw data. "Data_Removed" denotes data removed during the correction process.

Water flow pulse. This field is used to denote the absence or presence of a marked increase in the river flow rate, a.k.a., discharge (Q), as measured at the USGS streamflow gage located n the Rio Grande at the Central Bridge in Albuquerque, NM, amidst the four monitoring sites. Since the gage is not directly located at any of the sites and the river velocity continually changes, the presence of elevated discharge occurring at the gage is not necessarily occuring at the monitoring site at the same time datum but still within ~12 hour.
This field is used to describe any notable or extenuating circumstances associated with this sampling
